title: George Rogers Clark National Historical Park: Clark Memorial Construction
body: Explore This Park    Learn About the Park     History & Culture     Places     Clark Memorial Construction                Clark Memorial Construction         Clark Memorial at Sunset National Park Service  The George Rogers Clark Memorial was a major feat of architectural engineering. Constructed between 1931 and 1933 it towers over the national park's landscape. Like pieces in a puzzle, the memorial came together piece by piece until the whole was completed. Memorial Construction Timeline          Pouring of the foundation, October 1931   Construction of the memorial began in September 1931. By the middle of October, the foundation of the building had been poured.        Basement of the rotunda under construction.   Due to a warmer than usual fall, work on the memorial proceeded at a rapid pace. By Christmas 1931, the basement of the rotunda was completed.        Layer of Minnesota granite placed around wainscoting.   By February 1932, the layer of Minnesota granite wainscoting was placed around the rotunda. The colder winter days did not slow the construction process.         By March 1932, the drums for the Doric columns began arriving in Vincennes. Each drum for each column weighed approximately 10 tons.         By the end of Spring 1932, the walls and pylons of the memorial were complete.         This last construction photo shows a project well on its way to completion by the fall of 1932. On May 1, 1933 the W.R. Heath Company notified the George Rogers Clark Commission that they had finished construction of the building.
